et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}fama{/it} report, fame; akin to Latin {it}fari{/it} to speak {ma}{mat|ban:1|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}a structure housing memorials to famous or illustrious individuals usually chosen by a group of electors
{bc}a group of individuals in a particular category (such as a sport) who have been selected as particularly illustrious

shortdef: a structure housing memorials to famous or illustrious individuals usually chosen by a group of electors
a group of individuals in a particular category (such as a sport) who have been selected as particularly illustrious

dt: {bc}something that someone or something is famous for or that makes someone or something important or interesting

dt.t: His {it}claim to fame{/it} is the invention of the stapler.
The restaurant's {it}claim to fame{/it} is its barbecue sauce.

shortdef: something that someone or something is famous for or that makes someone or something important or interesting

dt: used to suggest that glory/fame may not be worth what a person has to lose or give up in order to get it

shortdef: —used to suggest that glory/fame may not be worth what a person has to lose or give up in order to get it
